042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:30): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320, a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: I don't think we should define a new timeline
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:30): I think we should just use the Date.now() timeline
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:30): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: and have everything break when the clock changes?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:31): because that's going to break Web pages anyway
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:31): why not try to do better?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:31): ES5 says "The now function return a Number value that is the time value designating the UTC date and time of the occurrence of the call to now."
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:31): who are you directing not to do that?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:31): users with computers that use ntp?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:32): there's not a computer in the world with a clock that never adjusts
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:32): my understanding is that usually those adjustments can be made without going backwards
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:32): and if that's not true, it should be!
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:32): in practice they are not
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:33): you're gonna fix leap seconds for us?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:33): that sounds awesome!
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:33): fixing that is actually easier than fixing all the Web pages (and other stuff, I suspect) that depend on Date.now and equivalents not going backwards
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:33): well, i don't want to define a Date.now() equivalent either
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:34): in some systems there's a distinction between datetime values, which correspond to real-world dates and times, and intervals
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:34): I would handle leap seconds by just holding the clock constant for one second
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:35): for animations and performance monitoring you care about intervals only
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:35): it would actually be pretty trivial in the browser to record the last reported time and never report anything less than that
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:35): that would handle most of the issues
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:35): and most animation libraries do that for Date.now()
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:35): if someone's clock is just wrong, well, you lose
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:35): it's not useful for the performance monitoring case
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:35): because it biases measurements
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:35): for animations and performance monitoring you don't care about a 1-second pause once a year
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:36): yes, but in the real world NTP clock adjustments are much more frequent than that
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:36): ntp and other clock adjusting processes
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:36): how frequent? and how large?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:36): there were quite a few reports of inconsistent timestamps from early navigation timing implementations
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:37): i think typically on the order of seconds
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:40): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: here's one thread on the issue http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-web-perf/2011Apr/0029.html
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:43): the conclusion in that thread seems satisfactory

353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:43): another issue is that the APIs available to say "please tell me the current time relative to the unix epoch" are more expensive and less precise than the APIs for "please tell me how long it was since some point in this process' past" as the latter is often just reading off a cpu counter
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:44): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320: I thought Chrome used a hybrid approach?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:44): a hybrid approach is easy enough to do
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:44): yeah, but since we have to slew there can be some error
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:44): that's similar to what Boris suggested and the thread concluded, really
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:44): on windows the slewing error can accumulate into the measurable range
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:45): We could use the same "document time" for animation too
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:45): yeah, if such a thing existed
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (03:45): something like 'milliseconds since the document was created, ignoring any changes to the system clock'
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:46): I mean what that thread ended up concluding
